title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
description: Published in 1960, it is widely regarded as a classic of modern American literature, addressing themes of racial injustice and moral growth in the South.

author: George Orwell
description: A dystopian social science fiction novel and cautionary tale about the dangers of totalitarianism, published in 1949.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
description: A romantic novel published in 1813 that critiques the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
description: A novel set in the Jazz Age on Long Island, near New York City, exploring themes of decadence, idealism, resistance to change, and social upheaval.

title: Moby-Dick
author: Herman Melville
description: First published in 1851, it is the story of Captain Ahab’s obsessive quest to kill Moby Dick, the giant white sperm whale.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
description: A novel about teenage rebellion and alienation, published in 1951. It follows the experiences of Holden Caulfield in New York City.

title: The Lord of the Rings
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: An epic fantasy novel written by English author J.R.R. Tolkien, following the quest to destroy the One Ring.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: Published in 1937, it follows the journey of Bilbo Baggins, a hobbit who joins a group of dwarves to reclaim their mountain home.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
description: A dystopian novel published in 1932 that explores a futuristic society shaped by genetic engineering and psychological manipulation.

title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Ray Bradbury
description: A novel about a future society where books are banned and 'firemen' burn any that are found. Published in 1953.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Charlotte Brontë
description: Published in 1847, it follows the story of an orphaned girl’s journey through hardships and self-discovery.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: A psychological novel about crime, guilt, and redemption, focusing on the moral dilemmas of a young student named Raskolnikov.

title: War and Peace
author: Leo Tolstoy
description: An epic novel set during the Napoleonic Wars, examining Russian society and the interconnected lives of various families.

title: The Odyssey
author: Homer
description: An ancient Greek epic poem attributed to Homer, focusing on the adventures of Odysseus on his journey home after the Trojan War.

title: The Brothers Karamazov
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: A philosophical novel examining moral dilemmas, faith, and free will through the lives of the Karamazov family.
